Overload.descr: Adds an option to the conversation. Newest option will appear last.
Adds an item to a container. Best practice is to set a variable before this command, and have that be the "object".
Give the Party as many of the shape as it can carry.
Adds a spell to a spellbook. Returns false if the supplied object is not a spellbook or if it already has the spell; true otherwise.
Adds a key to the keyring. Note that the keyring is a global object; multiple keyrings will share the same list of keys.
Makes the specified NPC join the avatar's party, if there is enough room. The NPC's schedule is changed to FOLLOW_AVATAR, and his/her alignment is changed to GOOD.
Number of game ticks that should be advanced; 25 ticks are equal to one game minute, and 1500 ticks are equal to one game hour.
Toggles on or off a permanent version of the light spell. Flag specifying whether we want to turn the light on or off: true to turn it on, false to turn it off.
Checks whether a bit of text starts with a vowel or not. If the first letter of the supplied string is in the "aeiouyAEIOUY" set, returns 'an'; otherwise, returns 'a'.
Causes random damage of a given type to the desired object, subject to armor. See the full Usecode documentation for details.
Makes a NPC approach the avatar at fairly high speed. This intrinsic is subject to change in Exult. Returns false if the NPC is dead or cannot reach the avatar, true otherwise.
Ends the world and kills everyone in it.
Causes everyone nearby to attack thieving avatar.
Causes a NPC to attack the object with a given weapon. This intrinsic does not animate the NPC in any way; it only emulates a hit with the selected weapon.
Makes an NPC display casting frames until the end of its next script. If the second option is omitted, shape 859 is assumed.
Displays a book or scroll on screen. Text in the book or scroll is supplied through normal conversation methods.
Displays a book or scroll on screen. Text in the book or scroll is supplied through normal conversation methods.
Causes guard to come and attack a thieving avatar. SI uses specific functions for the local guards.

Checks if the avatar can walk from its present location to a specified position. This is similar to, but more limited than, the is_dest_reachable Exult intrinsic. If a third number is omitted, Exult will assume the Z coordinate is zero. Returns false if the supplied position is invalid or if the avatar cannot reach the supplied destination, true otherwise.
Creates a light which illuminates the screen. The duration is in game minutes.
Centers the screen on a given object or NPC.
Changes the frame of the face being displayed in slot 0 (top). This would be used to switch between Spark's happy and unhappy faces.
Changes the frame of the face being displayed in slot 1 (bottom).
Clears all current dialog options. Use UI_add_answer to add options.
Clears the desired flag for the given object. Many flags have immediate effects when cleared; most do not.
Deletes the string (if any) being displayed near the desired object. This clears barks.
Displays the targeting square and waits for the player to click on something. Array returned is the object clicked, and the x, y, z coordinates.

Creates a duplicate of the supplied NPC. This duplicate is always of GOOD alignment and starts with an IN_COMBAT schedule. The clone is placed in a spot near to the original NPC. Best used with a variable for further manipulation of the clone's settings.
Closes a single object's gump. Best used with a variable for choosing the object first.
Closes all gumps. Same as pressing Escape in Exult.
Creates a barge object with the specified width, height and direction. UI_create_barge_object(6, 22, SOUTH);
Creates a new object with the specified shape and places it in the game world at the supplied location. Coordinates can be x,y or x,y,z or x,y,z,map_number

Creates a new object with the specified shape. Returns an object reference to the newly created object. This object is pushed into the 'last created' LIFO stack, and starts out in 'limbo'; it will remain there until placed either, in the game world through the 'UI_update_last_created' intrinsic or inside a container through the 'UI_give_last_created' intrinsic.
Animates an object according to the supplied script after a delay. Works exactly like execute_usecode_array, but starts only after the specified delay.
Generates a random number in the specified range. Both minimum and maximum should be positive numbers.
Displays the specified location on-screen. Overlays sprite shape 10 over the screen.
Displays the main game map. Will also display the sextant crosshairs if the party has a sextant.
Displays the given map centered in the screen.
Causes the screen to shake. Also plays the earthquake sound effect at the start of the screen shake.
Shows any pending text and removes all faces from the screen. Usually safe to skip this in Exult.

Prints the input variables to 'stdout'. Very useful for mod debugging. One to twelve parameters of any type, whether or not they are arrays. Please note that the original games only one parameter was accepted. UI_error_message("Text to appear in stdout.txt");
Animates an object according to the supplied script.

Get the direction from one location or object to another. This intrinsic is aliased under the name 'direction_from'; they are both equivalent in Exult. Has a multitude of options, see the main Usecode documentation.

Searches a large area around the avatar looking for other objects of the specified shape. Returns an array containing all objects of the given shape that are located within 192 tiles of the avatar. This array is sorted from right to left, closest first. You cannot find eggs, barges, invisible or transparent objects with this intrinsic.

Searches a specified area looking for objects matching a given criteria. The mask value controls what can be found; using the proper mask, you can find eggs, barges, invisible or transparent objects with this intrinsic. Has a multitude of options, see the main Usecode documentation.
Searches the area around a given object looking for other objects of a specified type. You cannot find eggs, barges, invisible or transparent objects with this intrinsic.
Finds the first object matching the search criteria. Has a multitude of options, see the main Usecode documentation.
Causes the given object to fire a high-speed missile in the supplied direction.
Momentarily changes the mouse cursor to another shape.
Returns the game hour in 24 hour format. hour = UI_game_hour();
Returns the game minute in 0-59 format. minute = UI_game_minute();
Returns a number describing the NPC's attitude towards the avatar. Can be one of the following values: 0 Neutral, 1 Good, 2, Evil, 3 Chaotic
If supplied with a valid array, returns the number of elements in the array; otherwise, returns 1.

Returns a numeric value specifying how the NPC behaves in combat. Possible values are: NEAREST = 0 WEAKEST = 1 STRONGEST = 2 BERSERK = 3 PROTECT = 4 DEFEND = 5 FLANK = 6 FLEE = 7 RANDOM = 8 MANUAL = 9
Gets an object reference to the avatar.

Checks the barge upon which the supplied object is on. Returns zero if no valid object is passed, or if the object is not lying on a barge. Otherwise, returns the object reference of the barge (shape 961) object upon which the supplied object lies.

Inspects what NPC is associated with the given dead body. If the supplied object is the dead body of an NPC, returns the NPC's number, as reported by get_npc_num intrinsic call; otherwise, returns zero.
Gets the container of the supplied object. Return is zero if the object is directly in the game world, or an object reference to its immediate container otherwise.
Looks for all objects matching a given search criteria that are contained in the supplied object. UI_get_cont_items(AVATAR, SHAPE_SPINDLE_OF_THREAD, QUALITY_ANY, FRAME_ANY);

Gets a list of all dead party members near a given object. Returns an array containing object references to the bodies of all dead party members within 50 tiles of the given object, or zero if no party members were found. Not used in SI Usecode.
Gets the distance between two objects. Returns the distance between the two objects, or zero if one or both of the parameters is not a valid object.
Inspects the chosen flag of the given object. met = UI_get_item_flag(CELLIA, MET);
Gets the current frame of the desired object, without the rotation bit. Returns frame number from 0-31.
Sets the current frame of the desired object, preserving the rotation bit. Returns frame number from 0-63.
Gets the quality of the desired object. Returns the quality of the object if it has it, zero otherwise.
Gets the quantity of the desired object.
Gets the current shape of the desired object.
Checks an object's weight.
Gets how far above the ground the object is.
Checks which map an object is in. Returns the map in which the object is located, or -1 if the object is nowhere.
If music is enabled and a song is playing, returns the track number of the current song. Otherwise, return is -1.
Retrieves a NPC's identity. This identity has no real effect other than that given to it by usecode. Typically used to give spawned generic NPCs like Moonshade's Rangers consistent behavior.
Returns the NPC's number. This is a negative number for all 'true' NPCs, -356 for the avatar, 1 for monsters or zero for anything that is not a valid NPC.
Gets the NPC object references of one or more NPC numbers.
Gets the current value of an object's or NPC's property. Despite the name, this intrinsic can also be called for any object, although most properties will be unavailable for anything but NPCs.
Inspects the warmth given by a NPC's equipment. Returns the combined warmth given by all objects worn by the NPC, or -75 if supplied with anything but a valid NPC.
Gets the current location the desired object.

Gets whoever is attacking the supplied NPC. This oppressor can be set through usecode, but it is also automatically set to whomever has last attacked (caused damage to) the supplied NPC. It is also set whenever an NPC acquires a new target -- this NPC will be set as its target's oppressor.
Gets a list of all party members.
Gets a list of all party members.
Generates a random number, similar to rolling a dice of the given side. Returns zero if max is zero; otherwise, a random number ranging from 1 to max.
Inspects the given equipment slot in an NPC.
Gets the current schedule of an NPC.
Obtains the avatar's skin color. Returns a numeric value describing the avatar's skin color. The return values are determined by a table in 'avatar_data.txt'.
Determines the currently playing speech track.

Inspects a NPC's temperature. The NPC's temperature changes over time depending on whether or not his FREEZE flag is set. Returns a numeric value in the 0-63 range specifying how cold the NPC is; 0 being normal temperature and 63 being freezing cold.

Inspects a NPC's temperature zone. The temperature zone is a grouping of temperature ranges that determine how the NPC is affected by the cold. Like the NPC's temperature, it changes over time depending on whether or not his FREEZE flag is set.

AutoComplete.KeyWord: <Overload retVal="int" descr="Gets how many hours elapsed since the timer was set. If the specified timer has been initialized by a previous call to 'UI_set_timer' intrinsic, the return is the number of hours since the initialization (or reinitialization) of the timer. Uninitialized timers return a random number in the 0-12 hour range. if (UI_get_timer(MAKE_CLOAK_TIMER) < 23) // Cloak not ready response">

<Overload retVal="int" descr="Gets the usecode function number of an object. This takes into consideration a NPC's assigned function (if any) and the correct shape <> function mapping for shapes > 1024.">

Overload.descr: Inspect what type of weapon an NPC is using. Returns zero if no weapon, one- or two-handed, is wielded by the NPC. Otherwise, the shape in 'SHAPES.VGA' of the weapon being used.

Returns the current weather state. Return values are: CLEAR_WEATHER = 0 No clouds, no precipitation. SNOWING = 1 Snowing. RAIN = 2 Raining. SPARKLE = 3 Magical storm, causes magic to fail. FOG = 4 Nothing happens. OVERCAST = 5 Light cloud cover. CLOUDY = 6 Heavy cloud cover.
Terminates usecode scripts that animate the supplied object. Scripts that include the 'nohalt' command are not affected by this intrinsic.
Checks if a spellbook has one particular spell. Returns true if the supplied object is a spellbook and contains the spell; false otherwise.
Checks if the avatar is in combat. Returns true if the avatar is in combat mode, false otherwise.
Toggles infravision for the given NPC. Only effects party members.
Returns 'true' if showing gumps, 'false' otherwise.
Initializes the face information for a conversation. In Exult, it is usually safe to skip it.
Prompts the player for numerical input with the bar slider.
Checks if an object is currently executing any usecode scripts. Returns true if there are any scripts for the specified object, false otherwise.
Checks whether or not the actor is transversing a path due to path_run_usecode or si_path_run_usecode intrinsics. Returns true if the NPC is still walking a usecode path, false otherwise.
Checks if the NPC is dead or alive. This is equivalent to checking if the 'DEAD' flag is set. Returns true if the NPC is dead, false otherwise.
Checks if a NPC can walk from its present location to a specified position. Returns true if the NPC can walk to the supplied destination, false otherwise.

Checks if there is enough room for a given shape in the specified location. If there is enough room in the given location for an object of the given shape and frame, returns true; otherwise, returns false.
Determines if a given object is an NPC. Returns true if the object is an NPC, false otherwise.
Determines the avatar's gender. Returns true if the avatar is a woman, false otherwise.
Determines if the avatar has a roof over his head. Returns true if there is a roof above the avatar's head, false otherwise.

For SI, it is better to use 'get_readied' intrinsic instead. Returns 'true' if an object with shape 'shape' and frame 'frame' is readied in ready spot 'spot' of 'npc', 'false' otherwise. 'frame' can be the wildcard 'FRAME_ANY'.
Determines if a given tile or object is a water tile. Returns true if the specified tile or object is a water tile, false otherwise.
Causes text to be displayed near the object. Does not have an intelligence level check.
Kills the specified victim.
Causes a lightning effect. The screen flashes, and the corresponding sound effect is played.

Imprints a virtue stone with its current location. Any subsequent calls to recall_virtue_stone that target that same stone will teleport the avatar's party to this stored location. The stored location includes the map where the stone is.

Changes the schedule table of an NPC for the desired time period. This new schedule is persistent across save games. The NPC will execute his/her new schedule in the map he/she currently resides when the time comes.

Makes the avatar lay down to sleep in the specified bed. What constitutes a bed is currently hard-coded (as of 2009/02/27). Once the avatar reaches the bed, Exult will call usecode function 0x622. If the bed is occupied, causes one of the party members to pop up and say so.
Finds out if the desired object is nearby. In this context, 'nearby' means within 40 tiles of the avatar. Note that, despite the name, this intrinsic is valid for all objects, not just NPCs.

Finds out if the desired object is on screen and can act. An NPC is considered able to act if it is not asleep, paralyzed or dead; other objects are always considered able to act. Note that, despite the name, this intrincis can also be used for objects.
Determines if the entire party is inside the same barge as the avatar.
Gets the number of 3-hour periods that have elapsed in full since midnight. MIDNIGHT = 0 EARLY = 1 DAWN = 2 MORNING = 3 NOON = 4 AFTERNOON = 5 EVENING = 6 NIGHT = 7

Causes the avatar to walk to a location and execute the specified usecode function when he/she arrives at the destination. If a path cannot be found for the destination, no usecode will be executed unless a call to set_path_failure intrinsic is made before returning from usecode.
The avatar can be prevented from reaching his/her destination simply by moving away from the path; this will cancel the effects of the intrinsic, and will cause the usecode function set by set_path_failure to be called. If you want the path to be uninterruptible, the avatar's DONT_MOVE flag must be set (this is flag 22 in BG and 16 in SI).
The other party members will follow the avatar towards the destination.

Plays the specified song. If supplied with a valid object or NPC that is on the game world, this intrinsic will also display the sprite effect # 24 (musical notes). UI_play_music(45, item); // xylophone
Causes an object to generate a sound effect. The sound intensity decrease as the avatar gets farther away from this object.
Plays a sound effect.
Clears all current conversation options and restores the stored conversation options, if any. The restored dialog options are those stored by the last call to UI_push_answers intrinsic.

Prints formatted text to 'stdout'. Prints an array of strings. The first element is the 'format' string. The format string gives the basic text, and has a placeholder for each of the other elements of the array; each element past the first writes its text at the next available placeholder. Placeholders are the '%s' sequence, without the single quotes, embedded in the format string. UI_printf(["The shape clicked on is %s", UI_get_item_shape(target)]);
Teleports the party to the virtue stone's stored location. The stone is forcibly given to the avatar if needed.
Causes a fixed amount of damage of the specified type to a target. This intrinsic ignores armor and armor-granted immunities.
Removes all spells from the desired spellbook.
Deprecated; use Usecode C's '(remove)' construct instead. Removes the supplied strings from the dialog options available to the player.
Scans a rectangular area for objects matching the given criteria and deletes all found objects.
Removes a key from the keyring. Note that the keyring is a global object; multiple keyrings will share the same list of keys.
Removes the specified NPC from the avatar's party. The NPC's alignment is changed to NEUTRAL.
Removes the object from the game world and from the 'last created' stack. If the object is not an NPC, it will de deleted; NPCs will still exist.
Removes the NPC from the game world. The NPC is effectively placed in 'limbo', and has its schedule set to 'WAIT'.
Removes whatever face is being shown in slot 0 (top).
Removes whatever face is being shown in slot 1 (bottom).
Hides the specified face if it is being shown.

Looks through the party's possessions and deletes a specified amount of objects matching a given search criteria. This function is an all-or-nothing function: it will delete all requested objects or none at all if it found less objects than the amount that was requested for deletion.
Removes the specified spell from the desired spellbook.
Unlisted in Usecode documentation.

Brings a dead body back to life. If 'object' is the body of an NPC, resurrects the NPC and returns a reference to the NPC; otherwise, returns a null ('0') reference. All of contents of the body will be returned to the resurrected NPC.
Brings the desired NPC back to life. If the NPC has a body, this body will be completely ignored; moreover, the NPC will be back without any equipment that was left on his body when he died.
Reverts the schedules of a NPC to those stored in 'STATIC/schedule.dat'. Can be risky for NPCs not in the original games.
Runs the endgame. Boolean value specifying the manner in which the game was finished. If it is true, will set the game-completion flag that allows the endgame to be viewed from the title screen.
Forces an NPC to return to his/her regularly scheduled activities. In SI, typically used after STARTED_TALKING to resume work when the conversation ends.
Saves the current position/map of an object. This persists across save games, but there is only one 'slot' in which the position is saved. Therefore, only the last stored position is available.
Makes the player choose one answer from all dialog options currently being displayed. Returns the index (ranging from 1 to n) of the chosen dialog option.
Makes the player choose one answer from all dialog options currently being displayed. Returns the chosen dialog option.
Sets an NPC's attitude towards the avatar. This change forces the NPC to reevaluate his targets, and may stop the NPC from fleeing.
Changes the NPC's attack mode to the desired value. NEAREST = 0 WEAKEST = 1 STRONGEST = 2 BERSERK = 3 PROTECT = 4 DEFEND = 5 FLANK = 6 FLEE = 7 RANDOM = 8 MANUAL = 9
If 'object' is a barge object, sets its direction (along with all objects laying on 'object') to 'direction'. 'direction' can be one of the constants defined for 'find_direction' intrinsic.
Centers the screen on a given object. If it is an NPC, the camera will follow that NPC.
Changes the active conversation slot.
Preassigns the return of the next 'UI_click_on_item' intrinsic' call. Can be just an object or coordinates. See Usecode documentation for details.
Sets the desired flag for the given object. Many flags have immediate effects when set; most do not.
Sets the current frame of the desired object, preserving the rotation bit. UI_set_item_frame(item, FRAME_BLUE_BURNER);
Sets the current frame of the desired object; does not preserve the rotation bit.
Sets the quality of the desired object. Shape must be set to Quality Flags in Exult Studio in some cases.
Sets the quantity of the desired object. The object's quantity is changed only if the object has it.
Changes the shape of an object.
Moves the object from the game map or container where it was and places it in the 'last created' stack. This intrinsic does nothing if the specified object is already in the aforementioned stack.
Moves the object on the vertical direction to a desired height off the ground.
Marks the given light source as being added to or removed from its containing NPC.

Changes the schedule table of an NPC. Accepts arrays after NPC. This new schedule table is persistent across save games. The NPC will execute his/her new schedules in the map he/she currently resides.

Changes an NPC's identity. This identity has no real effect other than that given to it by usecode. Effectively this is the NPC's quality number. Used for giving Pikemen and other generic NPCs different conversations.
Changes the name of an NPC.

Changes an object's or NPC's property by the specified value. Despite the name, this intrinsic can also be called for any object, although most properties will be unavailable for anything but NPCs. Note the delta does not overwrite but adds or subtracts from the existing value.

Makes the supplied NPC target the desired object. This does not make the NPC attack unless his schedule is IN_COMBAT. This intrinsic will reevaluate if the NPC's oppressor is actually attacking him, and will invalidate the oppressor if not.
Sets the supplied NPCs oppressor to another NPC.

Sets usecode to be called if an NPC fails to reach its destination. This intrinsic must be used after a call to either, path_run_usecode or si_path_run_usecode intrinsics, and will affect only the NPC affected by that call. If, for any reason, the NPC in question cannot reach the destination, the usecode function assigned by this intrinsic will be run.

Makes an NPC take a different, temporary shape. The polymorphed shape is persistent across save games. The NPC can be returned to its normal shape by unsetting the NPC's POLYMORPH flag with a call to clear_item_flag intrinsic.
Sets the current schedule of an NPC.

Changes a NPC's temperature. The NPC's temperature changes over time depending on whether or not his FREEZE flag is set. Temperature is in 0-63 range specifying how cold the NPC is; 0 being normal temperature and 63 being freezing cold.
Resets palette to default palette, based on time of day and number of lights.
Resets a timer to the current game time, and increments hourly.

Schedules a NPC to attack the object with a given weapon. This intrinsic does not animate the NPC in any way; the scheduled attack only emulates the actual hit with the selected weapon. The actual attack is triggered by a script; in an Usecode C script, use the 'attack' command to actually perform the attack.
Assigns a new usecode function to an NPC.
Modifies the current weather to the desired type. The new weather lasts for 15 game minutes.
Displays a face onscreen for conversations. The face is a shape from 'FACES.VGA'. This intrinsic always uses slot 0 for the new face.
Displays a face onscreen for conversations. The face is a shape from 'FACES.VGA'. This intrinsic always uses slot 1 for the new face.
Displays a face onscreen for conversations. The face is a shape from 'FACES.VGA'. This intrinsic finds a free slot to display the face in or uses the second slot if there are no free slots.
Displays the specified map on screen. This is converted into a shape in 'SPRITES.VGA' in a hard-coded manner.

Causes an NPC to walk to a location and execute the specified usecode function when he/she arrives at the destination. If a path cannot be found for the destination, no usecode will be executed unless a call to set_path_failure intrinsic is made before returning from usecode.
The avatar can be prevented from reaching his/her destination simply by moving away from the path; similarly, a scheduled event or scripted event may prevent an NPC from reaching his/her destination. In these cases, the effects of the intrinsic will be cancelled, and the usecode function set by set_path_failure will be called. If you want the path to be uninterruptible, the NPC's DONT_MOVE flag must be set (this is flag 22 in BG and 16 in SI).

Causes the specified NPC to sit on the given chair. 'Chair' must be a chair/seat shape (currently, hardcoded to 873/292). For barge seats, also runs the barge usecode when everyone in the party is seated.
Displays a graphical effect at the given location.

Plays the specified speech track. In SI, speech also displays a full-screen face from 'FACES.VGA'. Returns false if failed to play the requested speech track (for example, if speech is disabled), true otherwise.
Any guards approaching the avatar to arrest will stop what they are doing and will start to wander instead.
Stops time for all but the avatar and party. Parameter is how long the effect should last. The actual duration, in seconds, is equal to one fourth of this value.

Creates a monster with shape 'shape'. The created monster has equipment as defined in its equipment record, and has a 'GOOD' alignment. If the creation is successful, the return value is a reference to the monster; otherwise, the return is '0'. In the originals, there was an additional 'bool' parameter, but it is unimplemented in Exult. The monster will be placed within five tiles of the avatar.

Deprecated; stores a usecode function for special script behavior. The next script call to the stored function (e.g., 'script item call fun;') will have an event ID of 'DOUBLECLICK' instead of the standard 'SCRIPTED' event ID used for scripts. Since Usecode C scripts allow calling a function with an event ID of your choice (e.g., 'script item call fun, DOUBLECLICK;') it is best to simply ignore this intrinsic.
Teleports the avatar and party to the last saved position. Note that only the last position stored by the UI_save_pos intrinsic is available.
Pops the last object pushed in the 'last created' stack and places it in the game map at the supplied position. Note BG returns 1 if successful, but SI returns an object reference.
Centers screen around a given tile. It is usually better to use UI_display_area instead.
Returns 'true' if the avatar is wearing a fellowship amulet (shape 955, frame 1), 'false' otherwise.
Lets the player move the screen around, keeping the avatar in its present location. Overlays sprite shape 10 over the screen.
